key_points: The UAE signed a deal on Jan. 20 to purchase up to 50 F-35 jets and 18 MQ-9 Reaper drones from the US.
The agreement occurred just one hour before President Joe Biden's inauguration, marking it one of the last acts of the Trump administration.
The deal was solidified through a letter of agreement between US and UAE officials, detailing the sale's terms.
The specifics of the deal, including cost and technical specifications, were established but the first delivery date, potentially in 2027, remains unconfirmed.
The sale is valued at approximately $23.37 billion, encompassing aircraft, drones, and a wide array of munitions.
Future negotiations could adjust the financial details of the agreement, particularly with Lockheed Martin and General Atomics.
The Biden administration's stance on the deal is unclear, though it has expressed intentions to review it carefully.
Antony Blinken, Biden's nominee for Secretary of State, emphasized the need to maintain Israel's qualitative military edge when considering the sale.
The US Senate failed to block the sale in December, with votes showing a partisan split favoring the deal.
Requests for comments from the departments of State and Defense went unanswered.
